awd_titl_txt: BSCER Investigator Initiated Development program. Justice-orientated Approaches for Data science Education (JADE)
awd_abstract_narration:
This capacity-building project, administered by the University of Hawaii, is designed to develop the investigator’s knowledge and skills in STEM Education research (SER) through participation in intensive professional growth activities including mentoring by a team of experts in STEM Education research, workshops in research methods and cultural competence, and participation in SER professional conferences. In tandem with the project’s professional development activities, the investigator will design and implement a SER study focused on the use of justice-oriented approaches in data science education (DSE) to increase participation of people from underrepresented groups in the study of data science. The research findings will add to the body of knowledge on best practices for broadening participation in STEM.

The investigator will engage in a comprehensive set of professional growth activities that addresses gaps in SER knowledge identified through self-assessment, including regular formative meetings with mentors throughout the project’s two-year duration. The research study will test hypotheses regarding the effects of justice-oriented data science training on undergraduate and graduate student participants’ justice-orientation, as well as sense-of-belonging, persistence, and success in DSE. Data will be collected via surveys, interviews, focus groups and reflections and analyzed and interpreted using qualitative and quantitative methods. The project will broaden participation in STEM and inform best practices for DSE that support transdisciplinary engagement and are inclusive of underrepresented groups. Research findings and intervention products, adaptable for use in multiple contexts, will be widely disseminated. Long-term societal benefits include the potential for improved economic mobility and self-determination for diverse peoples and engagement with regional and global justice challenges.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The JADE (Justice-oriented Approaches to Data science Education) project is supported by NSF’s BCSER (Building Capacity in STEM Educational Research) program. Housed at the University of Hawai`i, JADE addresses the national imperative to train data science (DS) and computer science (CS) professionals. These are fields where workforce shortages are exacerbated by underrepresentation of low-income, veteran, rural, and Indigenous communities. These gaps hinder economic resilience, limit the inclusion of diverse perspectives critical for innovative solutions in DS and obstruct fair access to well-paying jobs in this field. The JADE project piloted transformative innovations in the way we teach DS to maximize participation and success of all students—such as personal storytelling, project-based learning linking the classroom to real-world problems facing their families and community priorities, and enhancement of their ability to critically evaluate data and its associated narratives. JADE tested the central idea that today's students are motivated by social justice and that linking DS concepts and methods to societal challenges would be motivating and promote their success. Over 200 students participated in JADE across formal classroom and enrichment program settings. They completed a JADE Survey Instrument (JSI) that assesses their understanding of the role of DS in improving American everyday life, community decisions, and policy. JADE also piloted innovative teaching methods in an introductory DS classroom, where the methods achieved high participation rates (88% or higher) and demonstrated students' abilities to critique systemic issues, propose equitable solutions, and connect their academic work to real-world and community concerns. The resulting data from the JSI and the pedagogical pilots show potential for long-term improvements in DS education, equipping students with skills to address pressing societal inequities. Beyond its direct educational impact, JADE has catalyzed transformative professional growth for the lead investigator, fostering a new body of STEM Educational Research (SER) scholarship and the development of validated tools that will contribute to national capacity-building in data science education in the future.
